												Against all my instincts I bought this game. What I was faced with was instant regret and $10 less than I had beforehand. I am a very picky customer and I VERY rarely buy games but when I was told this game was like garrysmod meets legos I thought, okay maybe I'll give this a shot. What I was faced with was horrifying. I started up the game, went to create my character and was faced with the saddest excuse for a character creation system ever. It was so poorly designed and shallow that many would confuse that monstrosity for the work of ljn. This game is so poorly designed and it seems to be aimed towards children 6 to 10. It was a fair attempt but it just falls flat in my opinion. The video samples of the game were convincing so I thought maybe that the gameplay could be redeeming. After a painstakingly long loading screen, I was faced with terrible gameplay, no voice chat options and a painful amount of little kids. Among this little kids were "Pizza Man", "Buttman", and "Awesome Guy". This game has made me question everything I once held as holy. Please, NEVER buy this horrible, horrible game because all that awaits you is immediate disappointment. After I finish this review I am instantly deleting this garbage. It isn't worth the 50 MB it takes up. If anyone needs me I'll be weeping over the loss of my $10. I would buy this MAYBE for $2 but I would have to be in a REALLY bad way to resort to this game. Stick to flash games over this. They are free, you won't get burned, and you won't have the feeling of looming stupidity that I am currently experiencing. Spend your money on gum instead, a lot of gum. You will get more use out of it.

number of helpful: 19 of 30 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
r 12, 2014
												Well... It's interesting.I can see some people's issues with there not being enough parts, but the fact that you can make (or download) parts and toss them into an Add-Ons folder kinda gets rid of that complaint.  I think the biggest failing is the fact that the tutorial is REALLY basic, expecially where the wrench is concerned.  This game looks to be extremely powerful, but withot utilizing that power it's kind of like Superman having to remain Clark Kent because the world is made of Kryptonite.Now, that aside, I'm seeing a pretty nice game here.  The block selection is done fairly well, allowing you to customize your quick-bars to whatever parts you wish to use.  In addition you use the mouse to begin placement of a block, but then use the numberpad to fine-tune that placement.  This is great in a 3D environment, as it truly gives you easy control of your building.  It even goes so far to, when placing something wrong, tell you exactly why the placement was rejected (overlapping, etc).  Finally, there are enough DEMO worlds in this game that you can truly see all of the possibilities you can get into (as long as you know how the wrench works).When it all comes down to it, do I recommend people play this game?  Yes I do.  THAT SAID, continue reading...I do recommend people play this game, however I only recommend BUYING the game if you can get it at a reduced price like I did.  I got this game as part of a $2.99 bundle on Bundle Stars, and for that price this game is well worth the money.  Would I pay $10+ for it?  Absolutely not, because it doesn't have a strong dev team behind it, the developer has a really bad attitude, and I doubt it'll ever be "finished".  The most I'd ever pay is $2.99 for this game by itself...  That's a lot, considering I'm expecting the developer to see a lawsuit by Lego in the future.

While some may say that the community and player base is dead and/or dying, there are still plenty of fun things to do -- whether you're building a house, competing in a deathmatch or simply hanging out with friends. 												This game, this game right here is really, really awesome! It's like playing with legos, on the computer, and you don't have to buy the said legos. This game is what I have played a lot, just like another game I've played a lot. If you love legos, and are too lazy to get the money to buy real legos, then this game is for you. And one of the awesome things is that you can host your own server if you wanted, and addons are really easy to install. I recommend this game to people who have someform of creativity and loves legos. Just becarful when exploring the server list, there are some strange servers out there... not saying all of the servers are bad, just some of those servers could cause you to lose your sanity being there. I happen to host a server, though I don't get very many players thanks to certaint people who shan't be named for reasons that I will not tell you about. Though there can be some downsides to this game, it tends to cause weaker computers to crash, which is annoying since I have a horrable computer, but if you know what you're doing, and keep the addon count small, you'll be fine with hosting a server, and don't be afraid to ban people, they break the rules on your server, so it gives you the full right to ban them. And there are other people who complan about how bad the server is, and here's a little tip when dealing with them, simply tell them this "My server, my rules. If you got a problem with this, then get off of my server." and then ban them if they do not stop, and if you don't want them returning day after day, calling you some very rude, and stupid, names, then perma ban them, like I said, it's your server, you decide how it works, if people don't like it, then they don't like it. You can't change that. And be sure to be a very kind person so people like you, if you do that, more and more people will show up on your server. These are my words of wisdom for hosting a server, I'd share my wisdom on how to not be banned on other servers within five seconds, but I do not have time for that today. Good luck, my good people, you're going to need it. Also, check out my some of my guides for Blockland, I only have one at the moment, but feel free to check them out!

number of helpful: 34 of 60 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
er 16, 2013
												Blockland has a bit of a history. In 2005, it was a little work-in-progress building game on the Torque Game Engine. Being an alpha, it had (here comes a massive understatement) quite a few mods that generated a larger following. The full game released in 2007, and much more polished than anything seen before. Streams of updates from the game's sole creator (with some collaboration thrown in) in the past six years have created a unique game that nothing can hope to come close to.So, what's the main point? Blockland is That Game Where You Build Stuff. It's all on you, and the community. Using LEGO-like blocks to create structures in online multiplayer may sound mundane on paper, but the online part is where it really shines. The amount of creativity Blockland players have is nothing short of amazing. User-created add-ons like weapons and vehicles are plentiful, allowing for different and fun gamemodes within buildings YOU create, and an "events" system gives way for even more creativity within builds.An accessible sandbox game for such a price is almost a steal.

content:
y 1, 2014
												First and foremost, this is NOT another minecraft gameBlockland is a Garry's mod meet Legos meets [Insert anything here]Like garry's mod in the way that you make it what you want it to be, be it an adventure RPG, Modern day RP or perhaps a zombie survival Left 4 Dead.At least around 400-800 people are playing blockland at any given time, so it's far from dead, my only complaint is that Badspot (The dev) removed premade maps from the game, meaning any terrian you want to have you have to build yourself or download it from someone else.The game runs smoothly on most PCs so don't worry about your system specs and is a game i recommend to anyone who enjoys Garry's mod and or Legos, this game is a dream come true for me, hell, i even used to host the most popular medieval-rp server back in 2012.Also, you're not limited to being a block person, you're able to play as any NPC or rigged vehicle, meaning playable dragon characters which you can customize with different colors, tanks, horses.ect (Yes peole can ride you)Now when i said it's like Garry's mod meets Legos, i ment just that, in Garry's mod you have to download addons made by the community, which you can do ingame easily without any hassle, it's as simple as searching for a mod and click download.Currently there's a massive amount of addons available from dragons, flintlock weapons, lasers, lego weapons, LOADS OF VEHICLES OH GOD, and gamemodes, not to mention custom builds like giant fantasy castles and what-not.So to anyone who is unsure about the game or is turned off my the fact that there are blocks.This /is/ a Garry's mod game, with Legos, and quite frankly i LOVE legos.(PS, playable dragons and Hydralisk(StarCraft) characters are a massive upgrade from Garry's mod in my eyes, and considering how easy it is to create your own mods it's definitely worth picking up for those who have talent with Blender)

er 28, 2013
												I have been on Blockland for around 4.5 years, and is still not even near old. Every time I turn it on, there's always something to do, if you have a creative mind, this game is perfect for you. You can make nearly anything, houses, citys, spaceships, e.t.c. Even though the game comes with some default items, bricks e.t.c, there is a giant bunch of add-ons you can add to the game, to make it even more fun. Even though the loss of interiors and terrain has happened, the game is still as fun as ever. Blockland also has an event system, where you can make stuff happen, like make bricks dissapear, have them change color, and with Event add-ons, that's even fun too. The price used to be £18, and I think the game is worth it, and now, it's £7, so now you can have the same fun, for a good price, I am not even the tinyest bit annoyed about how I had to pay £17 and not £7, as Badspot (the creator) fully deserves it. I'm sorry for the giant review, but that's just how great and fun this game is. I could never understand how people can not like this game, as it's packed with a ton of stuff to do. I'd recommend this to everyone.

AUDIOSimpleVISUALLegoDIFFICULTYAverageVIBEGoofyCRAVINGGarry's ModON SALERarelyPROS: Lots of building options, tons of color, texture and block shape options to build just about anything you put your mind to. Mount, weapon, and interactive options galore. This is probably one of the best building games out there.CONS: Community appears to be entirely made up of very young children. There also appears to be no options for spawned features/copy-paste in worlds, meaning that you will have to download or make maps entirely by yourself, piece-by-piece. Controls are very complex.WORTH: It's worth full price if you're a building fanatic, but you may have trouble finding people to play with if you wish to enjoy the more multiplayer aspects. It doesn't go on sale as often as other games do, so you might have to wait a while for a discount.OVERALL: A lot of people say this game peaked about 5 years ago or so. I wouldn't know, because I wasn't there-- But it is clear that this game is full of potential that is not being utilized for one reason or another. It's disappointing that I will not be able to do much with my creations beyond screenshot them or show them to close friends who also own this.SCORE:5/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

content:
er 24, 2016
												The game overall is very funny and addictive at times, Blockland is basically a First-Person/Third-Person sandbox where you have the game world in your hands to build whatever comes out of your mind. With an environment editor, eventing system, a variety of bricks to choose from the game is pretty fun.With mods, everything changes, the game is absolutely much more better when you have mods installed to your game, these add-ons can include new bricks, vehicles, clients, scripts, events, and so on. There's also a new dedicated service called Blockland Glass, a mod hosting service and chat service that is basically a replacement from the abandoned Return To Blockland.The community is small, but you can find good people here, some are toxic, but that's what you'd expect from games. there's usually over a hundred people online every day, but at night around the US, it lowers. Numerous servers can be found though, and you have the ability to buy one from a community hosted service, or you are able to host your sever dedicated or non-dedicated.The last pro is that the game itself has it's own forum, called Blockland Forums, here you can find many threads and topics that mostly relate to Blockland, except the off-topic. Add-ons are mainly released there, and you can find many discussions, such as help with the game, making add-ons, or generally talking about anything else related to Blockland.The game is very fun in my opinion, and it sadly got it's last big update in 2013, when the game was released on Steam. Things have come and gone by then, but I'd assure that you'd have a good time playing the game when you have friends. My experience in Blockland so far gives me a rating of a 8/10.Blockland Forums can be found here - https://forum.blockland.us/Blockland Glass can be found here -https://blocklandglass.com/Blockland Glass Hosting Service can be found here - https://forum.blockland.us/index.php?PHPSESSID=8or55m13cuhi6ohrhos2ie0ej2&topic=303684.0

content:
1, 2016
												I remember having given Blockland in Christmas of 2009 (And re-buying and still playing it via Steam at this point). And back in the day, it tended to be a clone of Roblox in terms of building blocks and other notible assets. Which THEN, a few months ago, made people point out "AAAH THIS IS MINECRAFT BUT ALL SCRATCHY AND SHIZZ" and was going like that ever since. Yup, I know how you Minecraft peoples are.So for this review, I'm not only going to review this game, but compare this to Minecraft a bit, and why I sometimes like to dub this "Hipster Minecraft".So basically what Blockland is, is a first-person sandbox multiplayer create-your-own-anything game. SOUND FAMILIAR??? You control inhabitants known as "Blockheads" and build anything, Yup, quite familiar. HOWEVER, you do NOT start in a pre-generated world. It is a flatgrass-style area you find yourself in. All saves you make are only builds, and not whole worlds, which is not as convoluted as Minecraft as all you can do to get a build you made is straight-up load it like a schematic.Now for building things and designing games, functions, etc.: You can see building is quite advanced and more difficult than Minecraft. But it's great if you want a first-person Sandbox building game with more detailed models than Minecraft, as Minecraft is all 1-meter blocks and very flat compared to Blockland blocks. For functions, you can use a Wrench to make blocks emit light and particles, as well as implement functions to make games and programming. Minecraft pretty much does the same thing with Command Blocks, etc., but IMO, Blockland is more simple than Minecraft in terms of functions. Because Minecraft's functioning requires specific functions and assets, sometimes extra mods, to make a good mechanism. I MIGHT be missing something here, as I have never tried such functions myself in Minecraft, but I should say that you have no information to design Minecraft functioning whatsoever unless you use the internet, which I don't really like doing given how the Minecraft community is nowadays.Blockland may be difficult and advanced to build than Minecraft, with all the little blocks to use and everything, but I found that it's much simpler to build what I want without getting my ♥♥♥♥ kicked in Minecraft trying to obtain a specific asset for my work. People would say Minecraft is waaaay better than Blockland that they hate this game, but I'm one of the few who played it back then and had a good time, speaking of which...Everybody knows Minecraft is the way to go besides Blockland. But for the nosalgia, or stuff Minecraft can't as mentioned above, I play this. I'm one of the few who actually like this game and I'm glad it doesn't have a fustercluck of a community like Minecraft, which is what I was anxious to point out. I really admire how quiet and underrated Blockland and its community is compared to Minecraft, and even Roblox as well. (I also played Roblox and it was pretty cheezy). Minecraft's majority of fans has pretty much bubble-bursted, where Blockland is "Just right", however getting beat down by Minecraft.But I will say this as I finish up this review. Blockland came years before Minecraft. It is not exactly a ripoff of Minecraft, which I apparently am seeing an award of which this game attained. I give this game a thumbs up, as it was what got me going before Minecraft was all the rage. This is just my opinion though. I'm only proving a point about Blockland vs Minecraft, and NO I do not think Blockland < Minecraft. It's all the Minecraft tweenies that are implying that this game is crapple. When I play Minecraft, I have that feeling that I shouldn't be playing this game anymore, whereas in Blockland, it's calm and I don't need to be reminded by the overdose Minecraft has become. (I still like Minecraft though)

content:
19
												Blockland is a great game, in my opinion.I know that most of the veteran community disappeared, due to the update (v21) which removed maps, and terrain. It was devastating for them. But new players may not understand how maps and terrain meant everything to them.The developer (Eric "Badspot" Hartman) has given up on the game, and pretty much wrenched it on Steam as a last-ditch attempt to squeeze out some more money of the players. I believe the community have pressured Badspot too much. Take notice of my forum post: https://forum.blockland.us/index.php?topic=308505.0 Another thing: Barely anyone plays Blockland anymore. Back in 2009, 2010, or 2011, you would find thousands of servers and people on at once. The last time that happened when thousands were online, was on Thursday, June 26th 2014. 1843 people were online then. It went down over the next few days, but that was about it. If you want to know how much servers there were, guess what. On the exact same day there were so many players, there was 600 servers online. Not kidding. 2014 was the only peak high year that Blockland had post-map-terrain-update. Nowadays, there's only 100 servers! 500 servers less than it was in 2014.Blockland was born in late-2003, and was created using a 14-year old game engine: Torque Engine. If you want to create addons, you'll have to learn TorqueScript and some Blender. I'm not gonna lie, most players have created some *really cool* content, if you look in the trailer. Although, not really anyone hosts these cities or whatever anymore.Blockland is barely updated anymore, so don't expect updates. Badspot only does REALLY tiny updates, and I really mean really tiny updates. If you want to see it for yourself, check it out here: https://forum.blockland.us/index.php?topic=302905.0As you can see, there were only 3 or 4 fixes.The community is pretty alive and well, but most of the new community are just unpleasant. Take a look at this locked post, for example: https://forum.blockland.us/index.php?topic=308380.0What the he-- https://forum.blockland.us/index.php?topic=306053.0 --*BLEEEEEEP*If you are a fan of sandbox games with a Lego-style to it, then Blockland is for you. If you're not a fan of 14-year old game engines, it's not for you.

content:
y 3, 2014
												I'm not sure I'll be able to put my feelings for this game in words as eloquently as some of the other reviews here, but I'll do my best.I would like to start off by saying that I have, at the very least, 2000 hours logged into this game pre-steam. Blockland is the first game I ever bought, almost 6 years ago. Holy ♥♥♥♥. Back then, it was still $20, and I can tell you now that I would have paid five times that amount back then if I knew how much I would have loved it.Other people have already explained the building system and the events system, so I won't really talk about those. What I would like to talk about, however, is the add-on creation system. Don't get me wrong, I truly enjoy building and eventing, but I wouldn't keep coming back to this game as often as I do if there weren't any add-ons. Not even just using add-ons though. More than that: creating them, changing them, collaborating on them. Even though some of the coding may be limited by the engine in this game, it more than makes up for this by flattening the learning curve for making your own mods. In my honest opinion, there are way more possibilities for creativity because of this. Because more people are making add-ons, there is a lot more diversity and plenty of originality when it comes to gamemodes, server mods, etc. The reason why I said "at the very least, 2000 hours", is because of all the time I've spent in text editors, writing code. That's actually the reason why you won't see many hours played on my steam account for Blockland, I'm in the midst of making a big gamemode (look for it, people of the future). This game is where I learned how to do basic logic constructions and other similar things for writing code. The language is called "torquescript", and it's pretty similar to C in most ways. It's incredibly easy to learn because of the syntax checker (to catch any mistakes you make), and because you can instantly see the result of your code ingame. Because of my previous experience with coding, I've been able to pick up visual basic and C almost instantly. For my job, I was able to program a z-axis camera mount using C# and also to make a protocol for an x-y motion system using a custom compiler for visual basic. I've included these in my resume, and next year when I leave for college there's no doubt in my mind that I will continue using code. In fact, it's very likely that my experience with code will have helped me get in the school of my choice (already accepted to one of my top choices).While I know this isn't necessarily something that everyone will experience if they play the game, I know I just wanted to share my story. Know that even if you have no interest in modding, Blockland has something for you. I've never seen, heard, or smelled of a game that could truly have "endless possibilities". That is, except for Blockland.

er 17, 2013
												This game is mind-blowingly awesome. You want to abuse rapid firing rockets via an event system or just want to build a humble little home? Well, here's your solution.I reccomend the first thing you'd want to do is go to Start A Game and click on the Tutorial gamemode. Then start this game and make it singleplayer and follow the steps shown on screen.The game uses an easy to install add-on system, which is basically finding the Steam directory on your computer (Windows: Steam > SteamApps > Common > Blockland) and dragging and dropping your selected file into the AddOns Folder. I think this system will eventually be modded and changed to work with Steam Workshop like Garry's Mod. Once you have the right addons and knowledge of how to use them, the possibilities for a good server are endless.The building mechanics are very simple once you get the hang of them - simply using the numpad/your selected control scheme to maneuver the blocks into the right place and pressing Enter  when your ''Ghost Brick (Invisible brick you will see when you click the ground to move a block around) is above a support or another block. Then you can use the Paint Can (default key is E) to paint this block a selected colour.Physics-wise, this game is absolutely mad. If you think it's hilarious to have your car flung into oblivion then this game is definitely the one you want. This also kind of falls into the category of graphics. This game's visuals are not the best, but definitely better than Minecraft's. (Sorry Notch.)The game uses an eventing system which is a basic scripting mechanism. I think there should be a guide somewhere on the magic that is the Steam page, and that also tells you the rest about the game. Also, little LEGO guys.They're so cute.10/10 would build giant castle again.

content:
y 8, 2014
												This is my favorite PC game of all time! If you like to build things, this is one of the best games you can get to do so. There are tons of things you can do in this game, like creating DMs, RPGs, racing builds, and sports arenas. You name it and you can probably build it! You can easily make the things you want to build with good building controls and a nice, clean user interface. Plus there is even a very useful event system that you can use, so you can turn a light switch on or off, create bots to interact with your build, and much, much more! People have also created a vast amount of mods that Blockland calls "add-ons", using the game's built-in mod support. The only real flaw of the game, would be some of the community if you ever decide to play the game online, but if you stick around the servers that have nice people on it, you can have a really good time making new friends and just having a blast fooling around! There are tons of other features that I haven't even mentioned and some vital add-ons that make this game a lot better like the Duplicator and the Fill Can. All in all, if you like to build with legos and like a game where you can do anything you want at any time, just click that buy button! If you are a bit skeptical about the game and you need to experience it firsthand before buying, there is a demo available on the official website (http://www.blockland.us). If you ever do get Blockland, you are free to add me on Steam as a friend so I can help ya out! :D

number of helpful: 32 of 59 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												Blockland describes itself as 'that game where you build stuff'. That's actually pretty accurate!ContentBlockland runs on an older version of the Torque Game Engine. It revolves around what are essentially legos, as the title implies. You control a small plastic figure called a 'blockhead', and the core element of the game involves placing bricks (with very intuitive controls) and then changing them with paint, emitters, or a simple programming system to create pretty much anything. There's support for add-ons and a weapon system, which opens possibilities for team deathmatches and any number of other gamemodes.PositiveThe controls. Blockland's movement and view controls are similar to any other 3D game - WASD to move, mouse to look, space to jump, so on, so forth. The build controls are almost as easy to use. Pressing a numpad key moves the brick in that direction, just like WASD; the corner keys move up and down or rotate the brick, and numpad 0 clears your 'ghost' brick (which shows where you're going to place it). This does take a day or two to learn well, but once you figure it out it's hard to think of a better way.Blockland also has decent multiplayer features, and involves a player-hosted server system. One of the core elements of the game is the fact that you're not just building stuff - you're all building stuff together. Servers can, by default, support up to 32 players; a workaround has been used to increase this to 99. The fact that servers are player-hosted removes most problems with lag; each individual server has to have a poor connection to be affected, instead of just one master server (there is, in fact, a master server, but it only keeps a list of all the servers players are hosting; IP connections can still be used).Bricks can be 'evented', or programmed, to do a number of things. The events system acts on a per-brick basis and is actually very easy to understand. You choose an input from a drop-down box - like onActivate (when the brick is clicked) or onPlayerTouch (more self-explanatory), then a target (Player, Client, Brick, Named Brick, etc.), then an action (setColor, Kill, playSound). For example - onActivate -> Player -> addVelocity(0, 0, 10) would make a ladder rung, when clicked, give the player a boost up. More than one event can be placed on a brick, and they can be delayed or even chained together with something called a relay.Finally, Blockland has an extensive add-on system that can be used to change almost any part of the game. New bricks can be added, or emitters, or colors, or events, or any other number of things. Even the GUI is open for change; the only rules are those that the programming language sets. The programming language is, however, slightly limited by the game's creator; this is mostly to avoid hacking or cheating, which are nigh-impossible without illegally modifying the game.NegativeFirst - the game carries the potential for what I call minecraft syndrome. You buy the game and just LOVE it; then you play it for several weeks or months and abruptly lose all interest. I first encountered this effect while playing Minecraft, hence the name; I used to play both games constantly, and now I haven't touched either of them for months for no apparent reason.Secondly, the game's community can be picky. Just mentioning Minecraft as above might get me some insults and complaints; half of Blockland's community is notorious for their hate of the games Minecraft and Roblox, the sole reason appearing to be that they're similar to Blockland (or vice verse). Also, the game has a website with a forum; there's a good share of good people as well as an impressive number of idiots that can be found there. The community isn't horrible, but it isn't the greatest I've seen, either.Finally, the game lost some of its former value with the v21 update. This update removed terrains and interiors - excellent parts of the game that allowed landscapes and buildings to be used as the scene for construction - in favor of shaders (like you might find in any other game) and bots (what it says on the tin). The game wasn't ruined, but it was definitely made worse. Terrains and interiors may return, and I hope they do, but having to build on an infinite flat plane shouldn't hinder your creativity!SummaryBlockland's features outweigh its flaws - while the community could be nicer and some recent updates are questionable, the game has a solid base and a good number of features to support it. Its support for add-ons and mods make almost anything possible, and there's already a great number of these out there. If you enjoyed building with legos as a kid, consider yourself a decent artist, need practice with programming, or just want a good way to have fun with your friends - this game is for you.

												It's a game not like garry's mod, not like a map editor for those valve games, it really is a hands-on experience where you and some friends can make something in real time, not handing a map file over and over and playing tennis with a map.It's a game where you don't grab pre-made things from garry's mod and actually create your own structures / and vice versa. It really is like playing with legos on the internet, but with the modding scene for this game, the game feels less like a game for 5-year olds and more for new scripters to get into coding, as it's extremely easy to make a bricks/gun/vehicle/light/effect and put it straight onto your server for people to see.The community right now is filled with a bunch of angsty teenagers who like to ddos for no apparent reason, but it really is rare to have your server ddos'd unless you anger the community that much.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												PROS: - Gameplay is fun and simple - Numbpad brick placement is fantastic and easy to use - Multiplayer custom gamemodes and add-ons are endless - Character customization is easy and can make for some pretty hilarious character costumesCONS: - Graphics are not optimized for ♥♥♥♥ - Multiplayer Community is mostly dominated by cocky players (Hence, I said mostly) - Single-player can be boring. Otherwise there is no actual feedback from the game to the player.OVERVIEW:     I have played games like Roblox, Minecraft and Ace of Spades, and find joy in those games because of the community's creative standpoint, and Blockland is no exception. This game is the easiest one to pick up because it ACTUALLY HAS A TUTORIAL! (Which is still dumb because you have to load it up, there is no "Tutorial" button anywhere so you're left to find it yourself.) The controls are easy AND difficult. If you're used to FPS controls of switching through your weapons using 1, 2,  etc. Then prepare to be tricked as your bricks are assigned to your number keys while your weapons are located in your tools inventory by pressing Q (Or binded key). The numbpad can be used to move your bricks along a grid before placing them, which helps A LOT. Not a lot of sandbox, blocky games have this kind of feature and just makes Blockland much easier to play and enjoy. As for bricks, THIS GAME HAS A TON and more can even be added as add-ons, which by the way, is simple and easy to understand so you can install a plethora of mods made by the community. The Multiplayer in this game is really fun and most likely the only way you will play. The community is thriving through servers so meeting people in one place and finding them in another is pretty common and honestly feels nice because it feels like you are really getting to know the community and its players. As for Multiplayer gameplay, expect the normal Call of Duty like feedback from players. The occasional "OMG stop playing like that!" does turn up and its just as annoying. But if you're a troll and like screwing with players, then it should be no different than from how you troll on any other game. For the cons listed, I feel really upset that these are actually issues, because most of it can be easily simplified and fixed, fun-wise. The graphics are really up there in terms of quality. High graphics means your computer is somehow a beast because most high-end graphic cards can't run this game to its full potential. As for Singleplayer gameplay. Its just a simple complaint. This may be more of a personal standpoint so understand that this is mainly just a suggestion if anything. Singleplayer is NOT fun. It doesn't matter if you nuke entire maps of zombie NPCs. You will get bored of playing alone EASILY, and it is only because there isn't any actual user-friendly feedback coming from the game. I understand it's a singleplayer mode in a sandbox game, but even Gmod has a way of communicating with the player to make them seem like they are a part of the games world, immersing them into the game and grabbing their attention to want to continue playing.     This game is not bad, but your own fun has to be found in it, especially in the Multiplayer which can still give you a great taste of the game's actual feel. I do recommend this game, but it does feel like it can easily be put down.

content:
26, 2014
												I dreamed about a game like this since I was a kid. Played this game since it was first freeware (2004); the upgrade to retail in 2007 was worth it. I'd have more hours on this than TF2, if I'd kept track before the Steam edition.This game taught me about art, scene design, project management, concepts of coding (events system and modifying game files), and teamwork; but the best part of it, was that I was just having a good old time building for TDM builds and helping out on RP servers.When large projects start to feel like work, I can always start a minigame in the city I'm building to ski away from dinosaurs, or hop on a public minigame server to vent some steam. The instant chaotic action of TDMs, boss-fights, and, more recently for me, Speed Kart racing, does the trick quite well (I used to hate the idea of racing; that is, until silly physics-gone-mad collisions were involved). When I'm feeling more dedicated, I'll team up on a CTF, dogfight, or trench war server to satiate my tryhard tastes.But when I get back to that big project, and it's finished, it's the greatest when others can appreciate and experience your creation by walking the halls. Or running down them. Away from bears with pistols akimbo.A note for new builders: don't be intimidated by screenshots of massive-crazy-project builds. Start with what you know or feel is right. Your ability to create what you imagine will improve over time, like any art form, and will be greater scaling with the amount of time you put into it, and how many friends you have for work division and support.I started this game quite young, and having people tell me something looked good or bad influenced me a lot (very common in that stage of development); but I learned to pay the most attention to those who gave reasoning. Find someone like that, or be that person for someone-- they matter the most.

												I've been playing this game since 2009, and I am so glad it made it to steam.In short, this game is Garry's Mod, but made out of bricks. Let your creativity run wild to construct cities, spaceships, and so much more. Have fun in in various minigames ranging from TDMs to City RPs. Events let you change the behavior of bricks, from changing colours when clicked to managing an item shop. This game's only limitation is truly its players' imagination. What is missing from the stock game can be found on the forums in the form of Add-Ons, which expand the game's content, by adding bricks, vehicles, weapons, gamemodes and a myriad of other miscellaneous improvements or changes.I'd recommend it to players who appreciate the sandbox genre and any lego fan.

, 2016
												Okay, I've been playing the game since around 2007, while having varying interest in the game up until the present day. From version 9 and up, it was a great game, nearly everyone ♥♥♥♥ their pants when they heard about a new update because it brought new content to the table. Now it's rarely updated with versions that would constitute themselves more as a hotfix rather than anything else. We've arrived at the end of blockland's development and Badspot has practically lost all interest in the game. Is this a bad thing? For me, not really, seeing as there are always modders and mapmakers ready to enhance the game's experience. Let me tell you, there are many mods out there to suit your tastes, so I hope you'll never be bored with the different possibilities. As far as creativity goes, you can go all out and push the limits of the game if you have to. It's basic lego building but with the ability to not go out to your local toys r us and dropping 30+ on a set of legos. You can also play mini-games and other stuff in these worlds that you build.So to make things brief, the game is great. Go ahead and pick it up, it's only ~$10, try it out. If you don't like it, you didn't waste much.

content:
2014
												Note: to see this review in it's true form (formating and screenshots) go to:http://wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.com/2014/05/game-blockland.htmlBlockland is that game where you build "stuff". offten accused of being a copy of Roblox or Minecraft, Blockland is in fact it's own genre. its more of a Garrys Mod with blocks than a Minecraft clone. in fact Blockland came out in 2007 compared to Mincrafts 2010 release.Anyways like i said in Blockland you can build whatever you can image and build with blocks. i am not very good myself at building and creating but even then Blockland is fun. you can play gamemodes like Deathmatch using any weapon you want. even better Blockland has an "event" system that allows players to make extreme almost script like content.The best part of Blockland has to be the thousands of mods you can get for it on Return to Blockland, a mod within itself that lets you easily download addons for Blockland all most like Steam Workshop. what kind of addons? well all most anything, there are addons that add new bricks, addons that give you more weapons, addons that give you new things to drive, addons that give you different colors to use in builds, and addons that add gamemodes. some modders have added zombies and left for dead like gamemodes. there are racing game modes and plan old sandbox gamemodes.Blockland is uber fun with people online or even a LAN game. the problem is that Blockland seems to have network issues. regularly kicking you from games or even just not letting you join them. and as with Garry's mod if you join a server with addons that you don't have, getting them from the server will be a pain. i also wish Blockland had a voice talk ability in Multiplayer but that can be solved by using TeamSpeak or some such service.Blockland suffers from an outdated game engine know as Torque 3D. while the newest version of Torque itself is not bad Blockland uses the older version.the game did just get Shader support it came at the cost of Blockland maps. Maps had terrain and objects that where not made out of blocks. but because the Shader system could not support the maps they where removed. meaning the only way you can get terrain is if you build it out of blocks. not a problem for people good with the blocks and those with a good computer. because having that many blocks hits the Frame Rate pretty bad.In the end Blockland is a fun sandbox game that lets you do a lot of epic stuff. as long as your comptuer can handle it. it is in NO WAY a clone of Mincraft, Roblox, or any other block like game. if you enjoy games like Garry's Mod then Blockland will be perfect for you.

content:
er 16, 2013
												I grew up playing the original alpha of this game, it was called Blockland v00002, lagged like a mofo and it was barely playable on my Pentium 4 PC. But, most importantly, it was fun.Then a bunch of years later, this game came out - and it is just absolutely amazing. Think of it as a sort of lego-builder's Garry's Mod. Sure, you've got your great building tools to make awesome ♥♥♥♥ with your friends in the default sandbox mode, within the limitations (it's still lego, so you can't have any floating bricks, for example), but apart from that, anyone can create new weapons, vehicles, and entirely new gamemodes with the game's scripting language (the uh, not terribly excellent TorqueScript).And the builds you make can be enhanced with event bricks, which are basically interactive bricks that'll react to say, a player walking on it, in ways that you define in the game with a simple system. Some dude made a playable pong using that, which is batshit crazy. And awesome.All in all, I can't find a good way to end this, because I'm not a writer, but I really, truly love this game, and I wish more people would play it with me.Game of the year, every year, 10/10.

I recommend avoiding this. N//AI'll be honest, I can't give a detailed review because I haven't had a lot of experience with this game, and please take this into account, this is my experience as a newcomer to this game. I personally don't like recommending against games, but I recommend that people avoid buying this. I don't think this is a game worth buying, and starting now because the servers are almost dead. When I say almost, I mean I haven't seen it rise over 200 in the time I've owned it. It currently has 161 members across every server. Only 8 servers with more than 10 people in them (Their number ranges from 10-20), the rest consist of small numbers of people. And ignoring the overall player count, I haven't had a fun experience with the game. Not because it is a bad game, but it is an oudated one, and it isn't getting updated anymore. So you are left with a small community in a game that now has little to offer. The only popular servers right now are Role Playing servers, where you pretend to live alongside other players, and a few battle servers, but I don't enjoy these because of the ingame combat. There are also a few building servers with a few players in, but with the players ingame, I'd recommend getting a better where you are able to design and build.In this game, you start up, or join an already started multiplayer server. No disrepect to people who still enjoy to play the game with a friend, but I haven't had a great multiplayer experience in the larger servers. The players are active in chat, but I can never get into chat because it's just complaining, and arguing, and asking for a boyfriend etc. I'm not sure the age range of people still playing the game, but this has been my experience.

content:
7, 2014
												Blockland has been around for a long time, and has sadly been burried. People still play, but it lost so much popularity. It's a fun sandbox building game where you can build and program anything. The way you build stuff is very similar to real-life LEGOs, where you are not allowed to have floating bricks. The law of gravity is impossible to break. You can still make bricks float by making invisible and walk through towers under a brick. You can press the left mouse button to activate your jets so you can fly around. There's a spray can that allows you to not only paint bricks, but give them special effects such as rainbows and also make bricks transparent. You start with three tools; a hammer, a wrench, and a printing gun. The hammer lets you break bricks you put, but you can't break bricks under another brick unless the brick you want to destroy won't cause the other bricks above to float in the air. You can type /wand to get a wand that acts just like a hammer, but if you destroy a brick that would cause any bricks above it to float, everything above it breaks also. The wrench lets you do many different things with your bricks. While holding the wrench, you can click on a brick to view its properties. You can make your brick emit fire, or smoke, or any other particle that's in the game. You can spawn more tools, like a sword or a gun, or something that'll help you build better things. You can also program your bricks with events. Events are super easy to learn. I made a basic Windows XP computer with very little knowledge of events when I was a noob, and the results were satisfactory! The properties will be different depending on the brick you select. For example, if I use the wrench on a vehicle spawner, I won't have the ability to make it into a spear giver. I can only select from a list of rideable objects. If I use the wrench on a music brick, I will be able to choose from a list of music for it to play. The printer gun lets you put pictures on printer bricks. It's useful for making signs for things like stores, or for cooler security systems. Building in Blockland is lots of fun! You can also download add-ons that other users made from other websites so you can get more content such as more guns and swords to blow up everyone, or tools to help you build better things. I hope Steam workshop comes out for this game soon so it'll be quicker to download and find add-ons. Blockland also has a minigame feature which lets you disable and enable certain fuctions such as building or jets and allow players to get points for doing certain tasks. With add-ons, you can enhance your minigames and make them even more fun to play with your friends. You could make a futuristic team deathmatch minigame, or a survival horror game using the popular Renderman add-on based on the legendary Renderman! This game has endless possibilities, and I am really sad to see it die like this. I mean it. I am literally sad. After the extremely popular Return to Blockland add-on was gone, many people started to give up on this game. Return to Blockland made Blockland more social by adding private chat (much like Steam's chat), friends, and the ability to join your friend in a server they are playing. It didn't just make Blockland a better game to play it friends. It gave you better admin tools. It allowed you to download add-ons very similar to how Steam workshop works. Many add-ons lost some functions because they depended on RTB. The Renderman add-on was one of them. You can't control when he spawns anymore. I will always remember how much fun Blockland was. R.I.P. one of my favorite sandbox games ever.

content:
, 2014
												The game is great when you have enough people playing local, but most of the regular multiplayer is too laggy to be fair. But don't get me wrong, this game is still tons of fun! Similar to Garry's mod, it is easlily added on to, there are goals only set by the players, and there are TONS of halarious moments.First, I want to start with the gameplay.It is about as rock solid as the game will ever get. Blockland appeals to a broad audience through it's open ended ways of playing. For instance, you can build if you are into creativity. Lets say that you don't care for building, that is not a problem. You could join a multiplayer kart race, deathmatch or some other original gamemode that Blockland could boast. The only thing bogging this part down is the slow multiplayer connections and the TERRIBLE physics. And by TERRIBLE, I mean if you hit somebody with a car just right, or should I say wrong, you could in fact get a one way ticket to the statosphere. (Then again, it's not exactly bad when it happens to your friend, in fact that's halarious). If you have a good internet connection, then this game's multiplayer will appeal to you.Well, I don't really have another category to cover so...Pros-* Been around for 7 years, still active updates (sorta).* Easy to mod* Fun Multiplayer* Creative Structure* Solid, refined gameplay concepts* I have had no problems with the community so far* Good graphics for a block game.* Makes halarious moments with or without friends aroundCons-* The physics can be beyond bad.* Bad multiplayer connections.* Did I mention the physics?* Setting up a multiplayer server is brutally hard. (not really their fault)(EDIT: I found a few more)*The public multiplayer has the worst community you will ever witness.*Lack of ambition (The game feels like it's becoming more and more abandoned each day)In my opinion, this game is solid enough to achieve a 8.9/10Im sure people will like it, but DEFINETLY NOT everyone.But for only ten dollars, it's one of the greatest user created content games that predates minecraft.

												This is easily one of the best sandbox games i have ever played. it gives you both single and multiplayer, it has endless building fun, and tons of game modes for you to try out.The single player doesnt offer too much, you can build, there is also a tutorial, and a few other game modes (that were meant for multiplayer). 												Best game I have ever played. People may say the community is bad, which may be true, but if you're still a little kid you could just turn the cuss filter on. I personally would rather have this community compaired to Minecraft or Roblox, or maybe even Gmod. It's just the way a lot of games are.Anyways, here's why I recommend Blockland;•You could build anything - It's like having infinite amount of every color of legos (which I always wished was a thing :c)•Lots and lots of add-ons! You could get anything from cars to doors, to gamemodes (including Super Murder Mystery, which is my all time favorite. This gamemode includes a few players who are in the mafia, who have to kill everyone else.)•Small community, meaning a better chance of running in to the same person multiple times, helping you make friends.TL;DR, Awesome game, little kids just keep your swear filter on. Best game I've ever played.Over all, I'd rate this game 9.5/10.

y 6, 2014
												I have played this game on and off since 2007. One of the coolest things back in the day was being part of a building clan. For the most part, those days are over with the exception of a few withstanding groups. However, the community (at least most of it) is still very good, and I'm sure new subcommunities will form with an influx of new people. The possibilities in this game are literally endless, especially with the advantage of the RTB Mod, which allows you to access a database of add-ons for your game as well as communicate with others who are currently in the game. It takes a bit of patience to master the controls, but success comes through persistence (though persistantly asking for admin in a server will get you kicked!!!).I can't wait to see what's in store for Blockland as far as new game-modes, mods, and people! Don't be a Blockhead... buy this game!

content:
er 26, 2013
												[ Introduction ]:Blockland is a mix between Roblox (non-steam) and a bit of Garry's Mod, therefore looking and playing like a "Roblox done right".The idea of the game is great: allowing players to build things with LEGO blocks and host their own servers with different game types. For further customization and setting of servers, Blockland also presents a simple enough Eventing System (simplified scripting) allowing the user to affect the entities, game client or the game running in the server.[ Positive Points ]:- Freedom of creation: For those who like to create and host servers, there is a great deal of freedom in the game, allowing anyone to create and host an unique server.- Easy to learn and get started.- DIfferent gametypes, that varies from Freebuild to Kart Races (with or without guns), Team Deathmatchs, CityRPGs, Empire (Civilization-like mini-games) and more.[ Negative Points ]:- As expected, the worst part of the game is it's community, probably composed by many children (or brain-damaged young adults and adults). Some very annoying and immature/offensive/pornographic stuff is said on the chat in any server. Even some servers Admins/Moderators are stupid and may get into the way of the players (derping in the middle of a firefight, standing in the middle of a road during a race, etc). - Also as expected due to the large amount of stupid members, many people don't know how to read, don't bother or are simply trolls, and dedicate themselves in annoying others. Stupid players also ruin RP games, like "Super Murder Mystery" (Blocklands' Trouble in Terrorist Town counterpart), turning most RP games into TDMs with lots of RDMing. Many mods and admins do their best to keep their servers clean, but any player will see this happening many times.- Buggy and laggy collision physics on vehicles, make some game modes very annoying or take much fun away.- Build mode can be very boring to work with when using a laptop without a numpad.- Little number of players and servers (from my experience).[ Conclusion ]:If you can get past the annoying community, there's fun to be had in Blockland. Switching between game modes and the shared simplicity of the games is very fun. Forming up a group of friends to play on a self-made server is also a great idea.I'm pretty sure that Garry's Mod would be a better option, but still, Blockland has it's own vibe to it to make it worth a try, so try the Demo from the official site before buying.

6, 2014
												The story of an ex-convict recently released from prison, out to get revenge on his oppresive captors. He does this in various ways; Petty vandilisim, assault, Pirate Ship Deathmatchs, etc. The game requires an intellectual approach to its many secrets and story branches.You must be patient with this game, as dying is something that will happen regularly and unexpectedly. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys story-rich games, with a deep narrative and a rich backdrop that immerses you completely. Upon starting the game, you will be greeted with some of the best graphics currently available to the gaming industry. However this is only a small part of the fun and excitement Blockland delivers.10/10 Would buy again.

content:
y 12
												Blockland is a complete Roblox killer. And I'm not saying that it's bad. It's a MUST GET. Blockland is a sandbox game (just like Garry's mod) where you create things with blocks. I know that may sound strange, kinda like Legos in a way. But that doesn't end there. There's addons (oh boy, you saw this one coming didn't you.). You can grab new addons from the Blockland Forms or RTB. Just look it up on google m8. And slap on those addons to the Blockland addon folder. Now you got more blocks! ......what's that? Weapons? Vehicles? Oh so this is like Garry's mod. Lovely! Yes, there are weapons and tools for you to build or fight in custom mini games. Vehicles for you to race against your friends, so much more to play with! Hmm, if this is like Garry's mod...is there game modes? Yes, yes there is. From Speedkart to Xmas to Tutorials to anything really, you can download more on the forms and RTB. You can even customize your own character too. Well, that wraps up what I'm gonna say about this game. I highly recommend you get this game to fulfill your creativity. It's way better than Roblox ya heard?

												I don't have any previous history of the game before it came to Steam, and really don't care about some of the politics that surround the title.  My opinions are based on my play experiences.  I don't think it's fair to compare this to LEGO in anyway.  The blocks in the game do not go together in the ways that real LEGO bricks do.  For example I never found a way to change the direction of studs (SNOT building).  And the selection of blocks is very minimal without installing a bunch of extra mods or add-ons.In fact, the game seems to require a certain amount of user-created material to be something other than demo or alpha quality.  So if you're just looking for a fun out-of-the-box experience, look elsewhere.

er 16, 2013
												i've basically grown up with this game. it's one of the best games i've ever played as far as overall experience goes. the community is one of the best i've ever seen. the modding capabilities are better than any game that i know of, and the modding community is helpful and generous. it says a lot when it's common practice for people to volunteer their help on mod projects with nothing in return. the people i've met on this game make up the majority of my friends list and you're all wonderful. from a gameplay point of view, it's one of the best sandboxes out there. the building works well and the eventing system opens up a world of capabilities, even on a vanilla install (if you know what you're doing). and with the mods available, a whole world of possibilities open up. i would recommend this game to anyone and everyone without any hesitation. if you don't have it, get it as soon as possible. five thumbs up, two out of two stars.

content:
er 17, 2013
												This game ate up my afternoons before the Steam release. This game is probably one of the best sandbox building block games I've played, probably even the best sandbox game I've played period. The base game has a ton of content, but mods add even more and I'm sure there's a mod for everyone. Multiplayer is fantastic with a huge variety of player-made gamemodes as well as a fun-loving, yet mature community. The visuals look gorgeous (Especially with shaders on.), the physics are a treat to see (Especially if you blow up a building made up entirely of small blocks.) and each server level has a completely different atmosphere. I absolutely love this game and I recommend you get it if you love sandbox games and the Lego-filled memories of your childhood.

content:
er 30, 2013
												I've owned this game for six years and I can say that when I reach absolute boredom with all of the garbage-tier AAA titles that come out this is my first fallback.  There's always something to do whether it be building an elaborate city by myself, entering a trench TDM and completely dominating, or sitting enjoying my time with others. This game had so much potential when I first played it, and now I'm seeing these potentials become real game elements. The mod development group cranks out new stuff almost by the minute.  I've even released stuff myself. It's also really optimized and could literally be played on your grandmother's computer.I'm really impressed with everything Badspot has done with Blockland. I would guess he is probably swamped with things to do since this game has blown up on Steam, but he still takes the time to engage the community.  My hat is off to you, bro.Anyways, if you are looking for "The Game", look no further.10/10

content:
er 22, 2013
												I have thoroughly played this and helped it's development for around 10 years now. This is not a game where you learn how to play it in a month. This game takes a while to master the controls and knowledge of it. It is probably the most flexible, while still remaining stable, sandbox game I have ever played in my lifetime. Yes, it may seem like Roblox's evil cousin or a Minecraft rip-off or whatever, but it has one thing each of those doesn't; A fun-loving and creative community. Each modder is a valuable member of the community, infact; a lot of dedicated people (regular everyday gaming people) have been recruited into the staff more often than you may think.People will play this for a few weeks, not like it, and turn it down. Which is fine, this game may not be for everyone, but the reason this takes a while to get used to is because there's really no other game like it. It's like stepping into high school for the first time. It's different. Yes, every game has it's share of bad sports, trolls, and idiots, but once you look into the community and spend some time to master the controls, you can literally do anything you want. This game is a First Person Shooter, Role-Playing Game, Arcade Game, and so much more. And for those of you who have already given up on the game, I ask you to give it one more shot, to spend time to know how to work the game, and really let your imagination go wild. Everything you see in the photo previews were all built by humans who started out in your shoes. There is really no limits. Every statement where people say "If you can imagine it, you can build it", are all true.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
6, 2015
												Create your own buildings using bricks.Engage in multiplayer battles that take place in a vivid block world.Interact with gamers all over the globe and compete or cooperate.Block games have received quite a lot of popularity since Minecraft appeared 5 years ago. The market is actually invaded by a lot of games that look like similar just to capitalize on its success, but in order to be successful in the gaming world you do need to be innovative, and that’s what Blockland tries to deliver. This is basically a game where you can use bricks to create the game world in any way imaginable.Since Blockland is an online game at heart, you will have to rely on other people to create the game world how you want, or each player can create its own region and defend it against the attackers.There are also some situations or game modes in which you won’t build anything, since the world is already built. Instead, you will have the opportunity to explore the world and defeat the other persons you encounter, while also avoiding zombies and other NPC creatures. The possibilities really are endless in this game and most of the time the people that play it will choose what to do and where to go, since there are literally no restrictions whatsoever, and that is truly important.While the buildings in Blockland don’t seem to be affected by gravity or physics, you do have the option and tools to create a world that is very realistic and unique.The controls in the game are very solid and they give you a great feeling and appeal, which is surely important. Furthermore, you also have a lot of multiplayer systems into the game, including a player hosted server system which allows players to develop their own world and invite their friends to play.Bricks can be created for a certain event or programmed and there’s even a unique add-on system that really makes the game shine. The community for this particular title is rather large, much larger than you would expect and, of course, there are some situations in which you are not welcome to the server.Even so, with the help of the forum and numerous other additions, Blockland does offer a lot of ways to communicate, including the in-game chat. This makes the game a very good one for kids that want to be creative and come up with something of their own.Blockland is the crowning achievement of the block game mania, as it delivers all the tools needed by the gamers to create their own worlds out of blocks. Yes, it will surely eat up a lot of your time, but in the end the game is well worth your time, since it has so many features and things you can do in it. Replayability is at its best here and it’s guaranteed that no two sessions will be the same. It’s surely much more than you could hope for, and we certainly recommend it to anyone who has an interest in block building games.

content:
er 17, 2013
												Can't recommend it enough. I've played this on and off since 2008. Aside from building, there is always something new.The modding community is huge. Hell, the game practically revolves around it. Vanilla is nice, but any server you join is going to have lots of mods. From Team Deathmatches, to racing, to prison escapes, to building with some friends, there are many things to keep you busy.Development is always active, and with the new launcher introduced in Version 19, they're applied automatically and more frequently. There are always new content updates and bug fixes every once and a while. It's been like this for years, and doesn't seem to be slowing down.The graphics are good for a sandbox building game, but what more could you want right? Shadows and shaders have been a nice addition in Version 21, and anyone with a non-intergrated graphics card can at least run them on minimum. The game isn't very demanding at all. Aside from the studs, the bricks looks and act like your classic Lego blocks, and the minifigures have a nice, original design to them.In a nuthshell, this game is practically G-Mod in the style of Legos. And it can't get any better than that. If you're still unsure, there's a demo you can download to try out the game and mechanics yourself - aside from multiplayer. For an indie game that only costs twenty-dollars, you get a lot more than your money's worth.

This game has no boundaries, especially with the use of mods. You cannot undermine this game for its lego-style approach, because beyond that you have unraveled limitless, unique possibilities that could be expressed through many game styles and modes. The well-sized and expanding community is helpful and the developer does a superb job at connecting with his players. As well, it features TorqueScript, an easy scripting language. It's super-cheap for its value! My final premise on this title: This is an uncomparable, well-developed sandbox that is a definite must-buy for its pricing and community.

												I tried a demo for the game years ago, and had a bunch of fun with so little. Now I have the full game, and the possibilities are pretty much limitless. There is so much to do and/or create with Blockland. If you had a passion for Legos as a child, you might enjoy this game... a lot. It has the building mechanics of Legos, with the gameplay and versatility of Garry's Mod. The only setback for this game's potential is the community. There are always good people, but the majority seem to be pretty immature, but it's kind of expected for the type of game. Overall, I think it's a great game to have. It's very fun to play with friends! Also, feel free to check out my basketball server if you decide to buy.

ry 14, 2014
												This game is the ♥♥♥♥ man. I have played this game for 6 years now, and it has alot of things to do. Roleplays, Team Deathmatches, Capture the Flag, you name it! You can decide what to do or what to build, perhaps go to a battle server and fight against other people? Tired of the servers? Why not make your own! It has full port forward support, so no need for that cluttery mess! You can create nearly anything, and thats not it. Blockland has its own unique Event system, where you can easily configure stuff. If you still have no idea what kind of game this is, i'll tell you. It has the creativity of minecraft, a very complicated event system, what is a bit like redstone, but alot newbie-friendly. I absolutely recommend this game to anyone.

content:
er 30, 2013
												Ah this is such a great game. I've had this game for over 5 years and put in over 1000 hours into it before it came to steam, it's the best sandbox game I've ever played because there is just so much you can do. I may have been just a kid when I first bought this game, but it is still amazing, I would reccommend this game over Garry's Mod because of it's great build system, gamemodes, and events system, which allows you to manipulate items and do amazing things. For a simple example, if you use events on a block, you could make it so that by touching the block you go flying into the air with your butt on fire. There are numerous possibilities with this game, it's simeoultaneously a FPS shooter, a 3rd Person Shooter, a racing simulator, a Dogfight simulator, a Quake-Like Deathmatch arena, a City RPG, a Jail RPG, and anything you can possibily think of. This is all thanks to the numerous enjoyable addons created by the community such as different gamemodes and addons. Very very underrated for it's quality as a game. People try to compare this game Roblox and then subsequently judge it based on that terrible game, but this should not be the case, because first of all it was created long before Roblox, second it has a much better community, third it has a much better building system, and fourth it has much more possibilities in terms of addons, gamemodes, and maps.

content:
, 2015
												Blockland Is a great game. It's a virtual sandbox that combines the community mods of Gmod with the building style found in LEGO brick along with some decent lighting! The thing is, our community is dying. We need numbers (players)  now more than ever to bring this game out of an unfotunately impending demise. I paid for this game back when it was 20 US dollars, and even at that price, I believed my money was well spent. Thsi game has given me some  good experiences and great friends over the 4 years I have played it. I can't possibly recommend it enough. We just need more players to bring fresh, creative ideas back to the game. If you're still uncomfortable to pay the 10 US dollars, just wait for a sale, then the purchase will definitely be worth it.

content:
28, 2014
												A long, long time ago, in a galaxy far away, Eric "Badspot" Hartman casually experimented with the idea of making a lego-oriented game with the Torque Engine. You place lego bricks in a voxel world, drive brick cars, shoot weapons, destroy bricks with hammers, ski down slopes, etc... The kinds of things most kids like to imagine doing with legos.Today, the game has reached new heights compared to its early years. The creative side of Blockland has gone to new extremes with their endeavors. When you first enter the game, you might be disoriented at first. There is no direction; you just place and edit bricks, among other things. But stick around and explore, and the rewards will be greater every time. Build a house or other structure of your choice. Then build another; then another, and another. Improve your technique, and watch your skills improve as your builds become more elaborate and more detailed, realistic, and higher quality.Make the bricks do things with the Wrench Event system, whereupon you might begin crafting brick-event computers and contraptions, sci fi setups, RP games, and countless other possibilities yet to be explored...Explore online servers and see what the other players are doing; of all the things you might find, locally famous examples include: A 1:1 scale exact detail replica of the RMS Titanic, giant six-story spaceships, high-detailed yachts, realistic houses both vintage and modernesque, science labs, roleplay worlds, giant dragonflies, arenas, etc...  you'll find many visual examples of Blockland creations through this link: http://forum.blockland.us/index.php?topic=247866.0, the Blockland trailor, and of course on online servers.The game's add-on system is among the most prominent features of the game. You might consider searching out and downloading custom bricks, vehicles, tools, gamemodes, events, etc as well to enhance your potential. Most add-ons may be found in the Add-ons section of the Blockland forums.In all, this game will be well worth the money if you stick around and explore the possibilities. The game's path is yours.-----PS: Before you step in, beware: The Blockland community is, in general, exceptionally... er... badly influenced. There are nice people out there, but it is advised that you use your own judgement to find them, and beware that dwelling too long in the general sea of the Blockland Forum and many Blockland internet servers, your sanity may be at risk. I urge you not to let this effect your impression of the game itself.

												Alrighty, review time I guess.. I have been playing this game since early 2011. I've spent hours, building basic houses, making event builds, shooting guns, and so on. Pros and Cons time!Pros ------------------------------------------------------------------Lots of people on it everyday.Prebuilt saves.Moddable. (very much)Tons of addons EVERYWHERE.Cons -----------------------------------------------------------------No maps. There used to be, back in v20. This "Enviroment" is basically a cheap knock-off of Adjustable Plate on BL. (How I know? Used to have a map collection in v20.)Gets a bit repititive on Custom.Random raging kids (rarely I see them).-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Well, I'm gonna give this game 8/10. It's really good. I miss maps so much. If you got 10 bux, get this game.

content:
, 2015
												Blockland Is a great game. It's a virtual sandbox that combines the community mods of Gmod with the building style found in LEGO brick along with some decent lighting! The thing is, our community is dying. We need numbers (players)  now more than ever to bring this game out of an unfotunately impending demise. I paid for this game back when it was 20 US dollars, and even at that price, I believed my money was well spent. Thsi game has given me some  good experiences and great friends over the 4 years I have played it. I can't possibly recommend it enough. We just need more players to bring fresh, creative ideas back to the game. If you're still uncomfortable to pay the 10 US dollars, just wait for a sale, then the purchase will definitely be worth it.

content:
28, 2014
												A long, long time ago, in a galaxy far away, Eric "Badspot" Hartman casually experimented with the idea of making a lego-oriented game with the Torque Engine. You place lego bricks in a voxel world, drive brick cars, shoot weapons, destroy bricks with hammers, ski down slopes, etc... The kinds of things most kids like to imagine doing with legos.Today, the game has reached new heights compared to its early years. The creative side of Blockland has gone to new extremes with their endeavors. When you first enter the game, you might be disoriented at first. There is no direction; you just place and edit bricks, among other things. But stick around and explore, and the rewards will be greater every time. Build a house or other structure of your choice. Then build another; then another, and another. Improve your technique, and watch your skills improve as your builds become more elaborate and more detailed, realistic, and higher quality.Make the bricks do things with the Wrench Event system, whereupon you might begin crafting brick-event computers and contraptions, sci fi setups, RP games, and countless other possibilities yet to be explored...Explore online servers and see what the other players are doing; of all the things you might find, locally famous examples include: A 1:1 scale exact detail replica of the RMS Titanic, giant six-story spaceships, high-detailed yachts, realistic houses both vintage and modernesque, science labs, roleplay worlds, giant dragonflies, arenas, etc...  you'll find many visual examples of Blockland creations through this link: http://forum.blockland.us/index.php?topic=247866.0, the Blockland trailor, and of course on online servers.The game's add-on system is among the most prominent features of the game. You might consider searching out and downloading custom bricks, vehicles, tools, gamemodes, events, etc as well to enhance your potential. Most add-ons may be found in the Add-ons section of the Blockland forums.In all, this game will be well worth the money if you stick around and explore the possibilities. The game's path is yours.-----PS: Before you step in, beware: The Blockland community is, in general, exceptionally... er... badly influenced. There are nice people out there, but it is advised that you use your own judgement to find them, and beware that dwelling too long in the general sea of the Blockland Forum and many Blockland internet servers, your sanity may be at risk. I urge you not to let this effect your impression of the game itself.

ry 23, 2015
												I've wasted plenty of hours on this game because of Tezuni's Prison Escape server, I went from a normal user to a mod over a long period of time. Hell, it's still great too.Also, as for other game modes and servers. You're bound to run into the boss battle server, good if you want to play as TF2 classes against a player who picks a boss to fight against everyone else. There are other classes to play as too, but you can find those out yourself.Other servers range from speedkarting where you're bound to die plenty of times before you see the finish line, building forts with weapons, FNAF fandom crap, and city servers that get fun when the cops are asleep, all of these types of servers never last too long.So, that's really all I've learned from playing this game.

content:
, 2015
												Game rating overall- 7/10The good things about Blockland:- The gameplay style- Based off LEGO- Add-ons(Workshop shoul be created)- LEGOfied Garrys mod- Online featureThe bad things about Blockland- Issues that the creator is too lazy to fix- The games community(Seriously, they ban players from the forums for ideas on improving the game.)- Badmins- Lazy Admins/Staff- Newcomers(Possibly impaitient and annoying 8 year olds)The game itself is great, but the community is a problem. The creator, Eric Hartman(A.K.A Badspot)May have made a wonderful game, but he's too lazy to fix any problems. He bans players off the forums for having such great ideas on improving the game. Overall, the online feature is WORSE. Theres tons of admin abusers, banning newcomers, banning anyone who they think is good enough to stay. Who cares if they are trustworthy? Anyhow, the servers like Tezuni's Prison escape, Boss battles Is possibly the bestest servers out there. With steam, you cant make dedicated servers, but you can play the game like if you had the paid from website edition, where you can make dedicated servers. I give this game 7/10, Great and fantastic sandbox game, but creator needs to pay attention to his game's bugs and his game a little more. -Engicop
